description: Originally, a person that is sent in advance to arrange lodgings. From Middle English herberjour, herbergeour, from Old French herbergeor (French hébergeur), from Frankish *heriberga (“lodging, inn”, literally “army shelter”), from Proto-West Germanic *harjabergu (“army camp, shelter”). Compare German Herberge, Italian albergo, Dutch herberg, English harbor. More at here, borrow.

entries.meaning: A person or thing that foreshadows or foretells the coming of someone or something.
examples: Synonyms: forewarning, herald, omen, premonition, sign, signal, prophet

entries.meaning: (obsolete) One who provides lodgings; especially, the officer of the English royal household who formerly preceded the court when travelling, to provide and prepare lodgings.
examples: outward decency  […] is the Harbinger to provide the lodging for inward holinesse

verbs.description: harbinger (third-person singular simple present harbingers, present participle harbingering, simple past and past participle harbingered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To announce or precede; to be a harbinger of.
